content.content: Mobility is physical movement that keeps your body strong and balanced. Early mobility from a hospital bed helps to prevent pressure ulcers, infections, blood clots, delirium, falls, and muscle loss. Getting a patient out of bed safely to a standing position, a chair, and walking are ways to do this. [^98] ## Questions to Ask: - What is the patient's baseline mobility? - Does the patient have redness on their boney areas: heels, lower back, ankles, &/or hips? - Has the patient's mobility improved, gotten worse, or stayed the same? - What equipment is used to help the patient? - How often are mobility assessments done? - Is the patient at risk for a fall? - Do you see any balance, stability, &/or fatigue problems? - Are there problems with the equipment? - What is the patient's mobility plan? Will it change after discharge? - What are the patient's goals after discharge home? - What equipment will the patient need for discharge? - What are the mobility barriers for the patient after discharge? ## Equipment for Mobility: - Walkers - Canes - Wheelchairs - Gait belts - Lift chairs - Adjustable beds - Rollaters __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") ## Fall Prevention Embedded content: https://youtu.be/MhPFCRLevY0 1. Have someone with the patient 24/7. Don’t leave the patient alone if they are at risk for a fall Embedded content: https://youtu.be/GvX0AYUqeI0?list=LL31GglpqkW9B1NW8eHUZ-CA [Fall Information by the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/falls.html) 2. Call for help before getting out of bed. Use your call light. __Don’t walk if you feel dizzy, sleepy or not yourself.__ [^7] ![Call light](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/4CdrMBsvYQemEkGW06AAqk/6bf5524a457e19aba2aeff90f846e5cc/Call_light.jpg) 3. Mobilize the patient safely as soon as the doctor permits. Wear non-slip slippers or shoes that fit well. Clear obstacles in the room if you or your loved one wants to walk to the bathroom. Make sure an assistive device like a walker or cane is available for the patient to use if needed.[^7] ![walkers](https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hub/114266/file-16410688-png/images/c--documents_and_settings-ninar-desktop-walkers_and_assistive_devices_sm.png) 4. Take off your slippers worn over socks before getting back to bed, since they can pick up germs on the floor.[^7] [Making the World Safer for Senior Citizens by Senior Living](https://www.seniorliving.org/research/injury-prevention-guide/ "Making the World Safer for Senior Citizens by Senior Living") [^7]: Hallisey J. The Empowered Patient® hospital guide for patients and families. Empowered Patient website. http://engagedpatients.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/empowered_patient_hospital_guide.pdf. Published 2009. Updated 2012. Accessed May 10, 2015. [^98]: Brown CJ, Friedkin RJ, Inouye SK. Prevalence and outcomes of low mobility in hospitalized older patients. *J Am Geriatr Soc* 2004 Aug;52(8):1263-70. doi: 10.1111/j.1532-5415.2004.52354.x Accessed on November 3, 2020.
